solution_line_template: First, we need to determine how much Johnny makes in one day. To start, we perform {hours_job1}*{pay_rate_job1}=<<{hours_job1}*{pay_rate_job1}={earnings_job1}>>{earnings_job1} dollars for the first job.
Second, we perform {hours_job2}*{pay_rate_job2}=<<{earnings_job2}={earnings_job2}>>{earnings_job2} dollars for the second job.
Third, we perform {hours_job3}*{pay_rate_job3}= <<{hours_job3}*{pay_rate_job3}={earnings_job3}>>{earnings_job3} dollars for the third job.
Altogether, Johnny makes {earnings_job1}+{earnings_job2}+{earnings_job3}= <<{earnings_job1}+{earnings_job2}+{earnings_job3}={total_daily_earnings}>>{total_daily_earnings} dollars in a day.
We multiply this amount by the {num_days} days, performing {num_days}*{total_daily_earnings}= <<{total_earnings_5_days}={total_earnings_5_days}>>{total_earnings_5_days} dollars over {num_days} days
